texts.definition: Sets of actions that trigger additional effects than those that occur due to the individual actions.
markups: <style="Definition">Sets of actions that trigger additional effects than those that occur due to the individual actions.</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> are a sequence of actions that due to the order or configuration they are performed in trigger additional effects. The sequence of actions performed to create the effect can be seen as an action in itself, although more complex than ordinary actions and possibly interruptible even when the actions it consists of are not.

Fighting games such those in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tekken%20series">Tekken series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Street%20Fighter%20series">Street Fighter series</link></style> have only a few basic actions but by heavy use of <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> each character in the game can have the number of possible actions increased by an order of magnitude. The first of these <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> (in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Street%20Fighter%20II">Street Fighter II</link></style>) was due to programming feature but left in as a hidden possibility<ref name="wiki"/>. That the fighting theme is not an essential aspect of <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> can easily be seen through the very similar actions needed to be taken in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dance%20Dance%20Revolution%20series">Dance Dance Revolution series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Rock%20Band%20series">Rock Band series</link></style>).

The height of jumps many of the games in the Super Mario series since Super Mario 64 can be extended considerably by pressing the jump button twice, resulting in a ''double jump''. This maneuver is founded in several other games, e.g. as a special ability for the ''Scout'' class in the second installment in the Team Fortress series. Rocket Jumping is a similar technique based on jumping while shooting rockets at the floor below oneself, and was an emergent feature in the Quake game.

To receive the ''Doctor'' achievement in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed%202">Assassin's Creed 2</link></style> players have to first poisoned a non-player character and then successfully performing an air assault on the same character.

<style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> do not need to rely on timing moves in a game. The capturing method of ''Custodianship'' in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hnefatafl">Hnefatafl</link></style> can be seen as a <style="CurrentLink">Combo</style> since it require two different piece to flank an enemy piece. When making one line of gems disappear in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bejeweled">Bejeweled</link></style> causes another to disappear, this is also seen as a <style="CurrentLink">Combo</style> - players can plan for these and are motivate by the game system providing additional rewards for  them. Many of the powers in the fourth version of the role-playing game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> allow players to build strategy on possible <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style>, e.g. making use of giving enemies vulnerabilities or setting up for attacks of opportunity.

<style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> are <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> that are created by the combinations of other <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>. The original use of <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> in <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> required <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> and this has continued to be used heavily in for example games using <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style> (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dance%20Dance%20Revolution%20series">Dance Dance Revolution series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Rock%20Band%20series">Rock Band series</link></style>), but the pattern can be used more generalized in <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style> or simply any game where players need to create specific contexts, e.g. positioning <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> in certain spatial configurations or simply which game elements to bring to game instances of games using <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style>. A general form of <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> possible in <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style> games is when players can manipulate the turn order so that they get two or more turns after each other with no other players' turn in between; <style="Link"><link="flip-flop-events">Flip-Flop Events</link></style> is a special case of this when a player gets the last turn in one round and then the first in the next. The collection of <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style> can be seen as <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> of actions that each fulfill a <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goal, while allowing multiple <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> to be used together can also provide <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style>. <style="Link"><link="repeat-combos">Repeat Combos</link></style> show that <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> can be created from simply requiring players to repeat the same action several times within a given <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limit</link></style>.

The design of <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> includes deciding if they should provide additional effects or simply modify the already existing effects, how complex they should be to perform and if their execution can be affected by others. <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> can simply modify original <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> through growing <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric Progression</link></style> (especially when combined with <style="Link"><link="positive-feedback-loops">Positive Feedback Loops</link></style>) or introduce new <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Discontinuous%20Progression">Discontinuous Progression</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> are often used to provide <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, either as an additional <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> or as a way to provide <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style> - the latter especially common in <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> activities in <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tekken%20series">Tekken series</link></style>. While <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> often affect how <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> is dealt, it can have other effects such as introducing <style="Link"><link="movement-limitations">Movement Limitations</link></style> (being 'slowed') or <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> (being 'stunned'). Other type of actions commonly associated with <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> are <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bejeweled">Bejeweled</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hnefatafl">Hnefatafl</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> usually not possible (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%2064">Super Mario 64</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake">Quake</link></style>), and <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> can also be created by letting players set up the effects of actions or events so that the coincide; adding <style="Link"><link="development-time">Development Time</link></style> or other <style="Link"><link="delayed-effects">Delayed Effects</link></style> which players know when they occur makes this possible if they can try <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> their actions so they support each other. The presence or non-presence of <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style> in a game design affect <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> that depend on <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> or several <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> performing actions in relation to their locations.

<style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> do not need to provide <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> that directly affect gameplay. The most obvious choice is to modify how to add to the <style="Link"><link="scores">Score</link></style> players are receiving, but <style="Link"><link="goal-achievements">Goal Achievements</link></style> is another option.

While the number of possible <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> can create <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, the complexity of performing the <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> that exist can be used to create both <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>. While all <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> can be as complex as game designers wish them to be, those based upon growing <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric Progression</link></style> can allow players to succeed with variously long <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> and thereby provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style>.

The simplest form of making <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> possible to affect by others is through <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Actions</link></style>. For <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, the additional possibility of <style="Link"><link="collaborative-actions">Collaborative Actions</link></style> become possible since all these are forms of <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style>, and <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style> can be used to require participation by several players.

As some of the examples mentioned show, <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> can happen accidentally from a design perspective, but from the players' perspective this is more likely to be perceive as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emergent%20Gameplay">Emergent Gameplay</link></style> and as a consequence this can be introduced into games to make <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> more likely to appear. Given that <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> easily can provide many possible permutations, this pattern is especially likely to generate <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style>. A classic example of <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> from military history is surprising an enemy by attacking from two directions at once, and games can make this possible to happen through providing <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style>. Another common case of emerging <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> are found in games using <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> with specific rules on each <style="Link"><link="cards">Card</link></style> (such as most <style="Link"><link="collectible-card-games">Collectible Card Games</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="deck-building">Deck Building</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pre-Customized%20Decks">Pre-Customized Decks</link></style> allow players to try and build decks with increased chances for particular <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style>. Although possible to counter by <style="Link"><link="evolving-rule-sets">Evolving Rule Sets</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> can easily occur from these as well due to the cumulative risk of unexpected effects in the design.

Games can make use of <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style> to support players in learning <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> or to support <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> are <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style> that are created by the combinations of other <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>. Finding the time and context to perform <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> may require <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>, and <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> are often examples of <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style> that require <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> to be successfully executed. <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> based on <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> typically create <style="Link"><link="clickability">Clickability</link></style> as long as feedback is given on the progress of succeeding with the <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style>.

Being able to perform <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> can be a goal in itself as it is actually a <style="Link"><link="configuration">Configuration</link></style> of actions - and this becomes especially true when they provide <style="Link"><link="goal-achievements">Goal Achievements</link></style> (as in the ''Doctor'' <style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievement</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed%202">Assassin's Creed 2</link></style>). Games where players know that <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> exist but are not provided with instructions on how to perform them, i.e. those that have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hidden%20Rules">Hidden Rules</link></style>, encourages them to do <style="Link"><link="experimenting">Experimenting</link></style>. This can also be encouraged in games where <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> can lead to emergent effects. In these games, knowing how to perform the <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> is <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style>, a sign of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>, and the knowledge can be shared as <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style>.

As mentioned above, <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> can give rise to <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> and due to this the ability to execute <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> is a typically display of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>. A flip side of this is that <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> can cause issues regarding <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> due to them often having growing <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Discontinuous%20Progression">Discontinuous Progression</link></style>. For <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based</link></style> <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, the possibility to be able to plan for <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> can also cause <style="Link"><link="analysis-paralysis">Analysis Paralysis</link></style>.

For games with <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> are likely to occur if not all game elements have the same gameplay functionality and these <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> give rise to <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style> on identifying which exist and how to make use of them. The <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> developed in this manner is a likely source for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style> exchange between players. <style="Link"><link="gameplay-engines">Gameplay Engines</link></style> is basically <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style> created to allow <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style>, or increase the possibility for <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> up to the point were they occur continuously.

<style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> can create <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style> since the performance of actions may be influenced by <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> but performing them so that <style="CurrentLink">Combos</style> occur may be a player skill.

<style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="configuration">Configuration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gameplay-engines">Gameplay Engines</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collaborative-actions">Collaborative Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collectible-card-games">Collectible Card Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Discontinuous%20Progression">Discontinuous Progression</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emergent%20Gameplay">Emergent Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evolving-rule-sets">Evolving Rule Sets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="flip-flop-events">Flip-Flop Events</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric Progression</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="repeat-combos">Repeat Combos</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rhythm-based-actions">Rhythm-Based Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="team-combos">Team Combos</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="delayed-effects">Delayed Effects</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="development-time">Development Time</link></style> if used together with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deck-building">Deck Building</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hidden%20Rules">Hidden Rules</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pre-Customized%20Decks">Pre-Customized Decks</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style>
